text: We fly high above heavenly clouds.  Beneath a brilliant b sky.  A TEENAGED BOY'S VOICE greets us...
On any given day, your life can change in the blink of an eye.  It's a cliche, I know...
Descending through the clouds, we are caught for a moment a dreamy gauze.  We emerge to find ourselves gliding abov small town.  Descending lower.  And lower.  To Xenia, Ohi

...But a lot of cliches get to be cliches because they're true. Your life CAN change in the blink of an eye.  What I mean is, one day you're a regular chump, a wannabe something.  You're not even totally sure WHAT you wannabe...

We pass over the town square. A fine spring day in middle America. Red brick buildings with names like "Miller & So Drugs," "Two Sisters Gifts," "Nelson Family Market."   Yo can almost smell the rosy cheeks and moral fiber.
...The next day the doorbell rings and some stranger's holding your ticket to being SOMEBODY.
Still flying over the town, we focus on a TEENAGED BOY on Schwinn.  We follow as he pedals his way to...
A three story building.  Older, brick, sturdy.  Meticulou maintained.

It happens every day.  Dreams come true.  And not just for those dim witted chain-smoking hillbillies you see on TV.  You know, the ones who win the Super Lotto and spend their fortune on a truck full of Goobers and a new set of front teeth.  It could happen to any guy, any time...even ME.

A JANITOR raises the American flag.  It flaps proudly as teenager chains his bike to a bike rack. He glances up at the flag, which is reflected in his uber sunglasses.  When he smiles, in SLOW MO, his teeth seem t sparkle.
Uh, that's not me.  I'm over here.

We SWISH PAN to another teenager, locking his bike.  Meet much less glamorous hero:  TED NELSON, 17.  A decent look kid.  Not hip enough to be cool.  Not square enough to be tormented. He joins the other KIDS heading into the schoo
You're disappointed, I know. I admit, I was hopeless back then. The 'do, the shades, ugh. But I always had good taste in women.

CHRISTY MALONE, 17, fills her cheerleader uniform in all right places. We watch her at her locker. Also in SLOW MO Which makes even her most mundane task seem graceful. Wow just look at her stack those books.
That's Christy Malone.  Head cheerleader, love of my life, lust of my loins.
Christy glances off screen and SQUEALS excitedly.  Anothe cheerleader enters the frame, holding a newspaper called "EXPOSED!"  Christy reads the headline.
"Health Teacher Flunks Her Own Lesson!"  No WAY!  It's Miss Pratt, smoking a doobie!
Christy calls to Ted....
Look at this, Ted! Imagine if we did THIS in the school paper!
She shows him "Exposed!" Ted gawks. Happy just to be this close to Christy. But they are quickly interrupted by...
Hand them over! Immediately!

PRINCIPAL RICHARD MERKIN, mid-50's, marches down the hall seizing copies of "EXPOSED!" from students' hands. We can that it is a "homemade" looking newspaper. And there's obviously much ado about it.  Christy winks at Ted as she hides the newspaper in her locker.   FREEZE FRAME ON Christy, WINKING.

Look at that smile.  That wink. That's no platonic wink. That's a wink that says, "I don't just want you, Ted. I NEED you." So of course I had to ask her to the prom. I mean, she was practically begging for it.

Ted ambles toward Christy. Struggling for nonchalance.  S limbers up by stretching her leg high against the wall. S whispers to another CHEERLEADER.  They giggle.  Then Chri turns to Ted.  Flashing that perfect smile of hers.
Just the guy I've been looking for.
Ted wipes his sweaty palms on his jeans...
I've been looking for you, too.
Christy continues stretching.  Driving Ted crazy with her contortionist moves.
Wouldn't it be awesome if we were about to say the exact same thing?
(sotto) From your lips, to God's ears.
You go first.
Ladies first.  I insist.
Well. The prom's coming up.
Yeah?
And I was wondering.
Yeah?
If you don't have...I mean...
She looks up at him with gorgeous blue eyes. Then blurts.
Teddy? Would you please please please take me to the prom?
SHUT UP!  Are you serious? Of course I will...of course.
Christy joyously jumps into Ted's arms.  Wrapping her leg around him in a passionate embrace.  The entire room APPLAUDS.
You are the most wonderful guy in the whole wide world, and I love you madly, Teddy Nelson!
And just as she's about to plant one right on his lips...

The shrill ringing of a TORNADO DRILL ALARM snaps Ted out his reverie. A large glass window separates Ted's EDITOR- CHIEF office from the rest of the school newsroom.  We realize now that Ted has only been gazing through the win at Christy, watching her stretch those gorgeous limbs of hers.
Sorry about that.  A cheap trick, I know.  But it's my story and my fantasy. So cut me some slack.
He follows the other students to...

Ted joins his schoolmates, lining up on both sides of the hallway.  Far from any windows. They all know the drill.  Christy's just across the hall from Ted.  He can't take h eyes off of her. CHARLIE DUKE, 17, approaches Ted.  He's got a camera arou his neck and so much confidence, it's a wonder he can bal his head on his shoulders.
Come on, bro. Spare yourself the humiliation, the degradation...
You and your pep talks.

Don't get me wrong. We can salivate over all the Christy Malones of our lives. Wishing we could devour them like melt-in-your-mouth filet mignon. But we're strictly hamburger guys. Ground chuck, sixty eight percent lean, is about the best we can hope for.
That's Charlie.  My best friend. He's into beef analogies, partly because he's a butcher's son, and partly because, well, he's just into beef analogies. What can I say? He's also a photographer...
Charlie kneels by the sidelines.  Shooting cheerleaders w his Nikon and an obscenely long lens.
...a very gifted photographer.

A cheerleader's ripe buttocks, peeking out from beneath a short pleated skirt.  As she kicks and jumps, her little panties wedge themselves firmly between her cheeks. The camera skillfully tracks her movements, waiting until... The cheerleader's hand comes down.  In SLOW MO, her finge slips under her panties and tugs on the fabric, pulling i over her cheeks.  Charlie's motor drive whirls.
The senior class voted him, "Most Likely To Have A Restraining Order Filed Against Him." But that's another story.
Ted and Charlie lean against the wall.
I genuinely think she wants me. I feel a vibe.
That vibe is from your wrist, pal. You've been over-tenderizing your meat, again.
Christy catches Ted's eye and smiles a perfect smile.
See? Did you see that?
She smiles at everyone, Ted.  She's like a newborn with gas.
Charlie secretly shows Ted a nudie magazine. "HEAVEN." A GORGEOUS WOMAN with perfect breasts graces the cover. A golden halo over her head.  Charlie flips it open.  Point a picture.

The only chick more untouchable than Christy Malone is Miss April.  (feminine voice) "Hi, my name's Ginger. I love tofu burgers, rainy nights, and riding bareback.  My biggest turn-off is cell phones during sex." Here's a tip:  set it on VIBRATE, honey, and don't be stingy with the lube.  (winking at Ted) Don't knock it till you tried it.
Were you always this sick?
One thing for sure, Christy Malone ain't lookin THAT good naked.
Ted takes a peek at Ginger.  Then at Christy.
Someday, I'll find out.
You have a better chance of being hit by a Mack truck with a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.
Ted grabs the magazine and flips through more pages. Beautiful, naked women.  Palm trees. Blue skies. Bubbling Jacuzzis. Red Ferraris. The stuff that fantasies are made Ted looks determined...
I defy your hamburger theory of life, and all of the unfulfilled hopes and dreams it represents.
That's crazy talk.
I defy any and all limits.
Charlie can see the look in Ted's eyes.  He's about to do something bold and daring. Something he'll regret.
Don't do it, Ted. Don't do it.
(walking away; defiantly) Any time, any day, a man can completely reinvent himself.
Ted starts to walk across the corridor, ignoring Charlie.
I'm warning you. This is an official warning. Danger, Will Robinson, danger.
A quietly attractive teenaged girl, JULIE CONROY, watches Ted. She seems concerned, too.
There's one more person you should meet. Someone integral to my story.
That's Julie Conroy. Unlike the rest of these losers, she didn't grow up in Xenia, Ohio. I just met her that day. But already, she had made a difference in my life.
Teachers mill around.  Chatting. Snacking on donuts, coff PRINCIPAL MERKIN bursts in, spilling a stack of "EXPOSED! onto a table. Everyone freezes.
Oh, Miss Pratt, Miss Pratt! What were you thinking?  How could you be so careless? (reading) "Exposing Hypocrisy in the Morons who Teach Us." That's the little bastard's motto!
The teachers turn to MISS PRATT.  We recognize her from t cover of "EXPOSED!"

(summoning courage) Principal Merkin, I realize we have to teach the children that recreational drugs are the devil's work, but that doesn't mean we don't dance with the Prince of Darkness ourselves, every now and again.
Ah, well, bravo!  That's just what we'll tell the school board.

Suddenly, an AIR VENT pops open and CRASHES on top of a coffee machine.  THE WHOLE ROOM, IN SHOCKED SILENCE, turn look at... JULIE, her head framed by the air duct.  She holds a digi camera in her hand. Her expression says: "Oh, shit." Principal Merkin narrows his eyes at the "little bastard" has been making his life hell.
Julie sits in a chair in front of Ted's desk. She and Ted size up one another.

Merk's punishment was cruel. Expulsion without appeal. Or working for me on the school paper. The school paper would be torture for a gonzo reporter like Julie and we both knew it. But what choice did she have?
Julie leans back on the chair, rests her feet on Ted's fi and blows a huge bubble.
So, William Randolph. Your last big scoop contrasted the popularity of Rice Crispie Treats and chocolate Snickerdoodles at the annual bake sale.
That's just one example. My reporting has made a difference.
Let me guess: retail sales of little chocolate sprinkles have gone through the roof!
The school dumpsters used to overflow to the point where the stench was unbearable. My award winning expose changed all that. The city added an extra weekday trash pick-up.
Julie deadpans...
Is it true? Is ignorance bliss?
Look, I loved "Exposed!" and I hate it that you got busted. I know the school paper sucks in comparison, but it's really not THAT BAD.
Ted's eyes wander to Christy, who prances around the newsroom.  Julie notices.
Don't even tell me you're hot for Miss Titty Pom Poms over there.
Christy's a very talented journalist. I see a Pulitzer in her future.
I didn't know they gave them for Best Lip Gloss Retention During a Blow Job.
Me-ow.
Go ahead. Ask her to the prom. Get it over with.
I have absolutely no intention--
--Do it. I triple-dog-dare you.
Ted nears Christy.  Students stare as he passes.  They el one another.  Whispering.
So you see, this is really about a triple-dog-dare. I don't even know what it means. I just know, unless it's a felony, a triple-dog-dare pretty much has to be met with immediate action.

Ted seems unaware that all eyes are upon him.  The cacoph of the corridor settles.  He gets down on one knee in fro of Christy.  Christy looks down on Ted.  Smiles that smile.  Which fre as her eyes dart.  Realizing that everyone is staring at with great anticipation.
Uh, Christy, I was wondering...
WOULD YOU GO TO THE PROM WITH ME?!!!
The corridor explodes with LAUGHTER.  Ted flushes with embarrassment.  Christy looks mortified.
(through gritted teeth) Ted, have you lost your mind?
You like me. I like you. I guess it's pretty obvious to everyone.
I don't LIKE you. We're JUST FRIENDS.
But that smile.
Oh, Ted, DUH.  I smile at everyone since I got my braces off.
So you'll think about it?
Christy laughs derisively.
You really don't get it, do you? I am genetically programmed to desire a big, buff, manly man who can defend and provide for me and my yet to be conceived offspring!  It's, like, a caveman thing!
So that's a maybe?
The answer is NEVER, Ted, NEVER. Except maybe in your dreams.
Christy flees. Leaving Ted kneeling there. Alone. Unless count the hoards of STUDENTS who are watching and LAUGHIN
In my dreams.  Of course. (repeating; chanting) This is a dream.  This is only a dream.
Julie approaches.  Gives him a hand.  Helps him up.
No, Ted.  This is an actual emergency.
Ted pukes in the sink.
I tried to warn you, William Randolph. She's got stiletto heels hidden in those Keds.
But you triple-dog-dared me.
It was for your own good, in a twisted sort of publicly humiliating way.
One word, my friend. One word. MEATLOAF.
Ted lifts his head.  Looks in the mirror.  Distraught.
There's gotta be more to life than meatloaf.

Not a hair above middle class. Home sweet home nonetheles Dinner in progress. MOM, DAD, Ted, younger brother, JIMMY mutt named CORKY curled under the table. A storm brews. Lightning in the distance. Thunder RUMBLES. Ted's Mom observes her son with unmistakable Mom-radar. S slides a slab of - rotten timing! - MEAT LOAF onto his pl with an unpleasant thud. Ted shudders...
If I never eat another bite of meat loaf again, it'll be too soon.
Ted's Mom frowns. Jimmy explains matter-of-factly.
Mom, Dad. Meatloaf has come to represent all that Ted hates about his mediocre life and the world we live in. He's what you'd call clinically bummed.
Why can't we have pot roast or stroganoff or even a little London broil? I mean, for god's sake, we own a grocery store!
Ted's parents look at one another, shake their heads. His gently explains...
We heard about Christy, son.
Jimmy tries to stifle a grin.
What is this? Does everybody know everything I'm about to say or do every freakin' minute of the day?
No cursing in this house, young man. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.
I don't have a shred of privacy in this whole stupid town!
We understand your disappointment, Teddy. Christy is a pretty, sexy, provocative, voluptuous... (catches himself) We...uh...we understand your disappointment.
It's my private business! Mine!
Can the tantrum, sweet pea. We're the good guys, remember?
Mom, Dad. Don't allow this disturbing behavior to furrow your collective brow. Ted's just experiencing some post-adolescent turmoil, coming to terms with the whole "small town dynamic."
I hate Xenia! I hate my life!
Ted charges for the front door...
And until that moment, this was the worst day of my seventeen and a half years. And then it happened. Three, two, one...
Ted bursts outside and plows straight into MARTY ZUKERMAN short, rotund man in his mid-50s.
Whoa! Sorry, mister.
Zukerman's briefcase and papers are knocked to the ground Ted helps to retrieve them.
In a hurry, are we?
I was in the middle of a melodramatic exit. It wouldn't really make a statement if I tiptoed out the door...What are you selling?
Bad news.
People pay good money for that?
I'm just a messenger.
Ted starts to back away. Instinctively knowing the bad ne must be for him.
Oh no. No way. I've had all the bad news I can take for one day.
It's about your parents.
Ted stops. Puzzled.
My parents? What do you mean?
I'm terrible at this. I blurt. I'm a blurter. Your parents...They ...well...they exist no further. (off Ted's confusion) Skinny-dipping. The Amazon. Piranhas. It wasn't pretty.
You've got the wrong guy. The closest my parents have been to the Amazon is the Brazilian pavilion at Epcot.
Well kid, I'm speaking of...your biological parents.
Ted sits on the couch, bewildered. Dad beside him. Mom po coffee in her best china.  Zukerman regards a wall of fam photos as he takes a sip.
The will reading is next Tuesday. Naturally all of Ted's expenses will be taken care of.
Ted's parents look worried. Mom reminds Dad...
We have a truckload of strawberries arriving on Tuesday morning.
(explaining to Zukerman) We own a small family grocery store.
How quaint.
(quietly; moping) It's spring break. I don't want to go to a will reading.
That's part of growing up, honey.
What? Having spring break ruined by will readings?
You know what your mother means.
All right, I can give you two tickets, prepaid, but you must be there. There's no other way.
Mom, Dad. Allow me to accompany Ted. I can assure you, I'll be the level-headed sidekick to your angst ridden teen.
I think Ted should take someone older, more responsible.
What about Charlie?  You boys could make it a little adventure.
Charlie, at a will reading? What did I do to deserve this?
Lightning strikes again.  Thunder rumbles a second later. The lights flicker. And it's PITCH BLACK.

Candles light the dark room. Rain pours hard outside. Journalism mementos all over Ted's walls. News clippings. Magazine covers. There's even a faux Pulitzer, a Christma gift from his parents. Ted's Dad sits on the edge of his bed.
I remember spring break of my senior year.  Seems like a lifetime ago.
Dad, please.
Grandpa was so strong back then. Working from the crack of dawn. So proud of his peaches.
Remember how you struggled through that whole facts of life talk and then found out I knew more than you?
You're way ahead of me again?

(proving it...) It was the year of the rhizopus rot. Grandpa almost lost the farm. You sacrificed your dream to go to the prize hog festival. And in the end you saved the peaches and you didn't have to slaughter your sow.
The lesson being?
Sometimes you have to do stuff you don't want to do. It's all part of growing up. And it usually works out peachy in the end.
I'm getting so good at this.
Dad chuckles, but Ted's still moping.
You guys are my parents.
Of course we are.
They didn't want me when I was born. Why should I care...
...if they're dead.
Son.
Well, why should I?
They had a rough life. Your father was a bouncer. Your mother was, well, a two-bit stripper. There was no place for a baby.
I guess.
They did do one great thing. They gave us our boy.
Yeah.
Be a sport. How bad could spring break in Los Angeles be?
I guess we could go to Disneyland or something.
Think of it as a rite of passage to manhood.
Like one of those "National Geographic" specials with the topless chicks?
Whatever helps you cope.
I guess it's better than having tribal patterns carved in my face.
There ya go. Always remember, focus on the peach...
...not the pit.
Ted's Dad hugs him briefly, laughing...
Always one step ahead of your dear old dad.
A 747 lands screaming on the runway.
Ted and Charlie exit the plane. They walk tentatively thr the sleeve towards the entry gate.
I wonder if this is what it feels like to be born?
Ted gives him a look.
Think about it...Long tunnel, bright lights, it's full of vaginal symbolism.
Poor Freud, turning in his grave.
Seriously, it's like we're being reborn. We really could reinvent ourselves here, just like you said. Nobody knows about your massive humiliation.
Nobody knows about your mental retardation.
Nobody knows you barfed during junior high school graduation.
Nobody knows about your constant masturbation.
And nobody knows you're a virgin! (after a beat) Aw, who are we kidding...
Charlie's words echo loudly through the sleeve...
...EVERYBODY KNOWS YOU'RE A VIRGIN!
People stare at Ted as they pass.
I think I'll reinvent a new best friend.

Ted and Charlie enter the terminal.  Friends and family w for loved ones.  A few chauffeurs hold signs with names. stands out.  Tall. Blonde. Gorgeous. In a short skirt. A matching low cut jacket.  And a cap.  She's stunning.  An she's holding a sign that reads: TED NELSON.
What are the odds of there being ANOTHER Ted Nelson on our flight?
Astronomical.
They grin at one another. Then approach the Chauffeur.
Hi, I'm Ted Nelson.
With a sad look, the Chauffeur hugs him, kissing one chee then the other.
I'm so terribly sorry for your loss. Your father was a great man.
Ted's stunned. Charlie leans in and whispers.
Who the hell was your father?
Well, Dad said...
Ted and Charlie sit on opposites ends of the plush interi Charlie eyes the control console with its slew of gadgets They practically have to shout to hear one another.
...A bouncer? Are you serious?
Maybe he got promoted.
Charlie continues playing with the console switches.
Don't. Touch. Anything.
Too late.  Rock music pulsates through the limo.
(shouting) This is the life, baby. We get ourselves some tail and we're talking SPRING BREAK!
Cut it out, before you break something!
For a guy about to try his first Dom Perignon, you are extremely uptight.
He flips another switch.  The bar opens.  Revealing a bot of Dom Perignon on ice. Charlie grins broadly.
We can't afford that!
Charlie grabs the bottle and starts to open it.
Don't you know anything about limo etiquette? Everything in here is included for our pleasure.
Wait a second, I thought we were hamburger guys.
And like every hamburger guy knows, when you get your one big chance at the good life, you abuse every second of it until they figure out you don't belong there and kick your sorry ass out.
POP! The cork flies through the air.  Bounces off the ceiling.  And hits another switch.  The sun roof glides o Champagne overflows from the bottle.  All over Charlie's crotch.
Nice. Is that in the limo etiquette handbook, too?
Charlie grabs a bar towel as Ted looks toward the sun roo Beautifully blue Southern California sky greets him.  Wit occasional palm tree swooshing by.  Ted rises.

Ted's head peeks out of the sun roof. Tentatively. Unsure takes in the sights as the limo cruises Sunset Boulevard. People stare at him. A beautiful BLONDE smiles and waves. waves back, very timidly. Charlie sticks his head out, too. Sun on their faces. Win their hair.
This is how the other half lives, bro. Enjoy it while you can.

The limo passes through the ornate gate of what could onl a sprawling mansion. It comes to a sudden halt. The door swings open to reveal a group of BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMEN. C in very short black dresses and even some black bikinis. expressions on their faces.
The MOURNERS embrace Ted.
Welcome, Mr. Nelson. You are so very very welcome here.
We feel your pain, so deeply.
(to Ted) Something tells me we're not in Xenia anymore, Toto.
The beautiful young women guide Ted towards the mansion. Charlie follows. A particularly VOLUPTUOUS BEAUTY eyes hi curiously.
I'm Charles. The handsome, devoted best friend. We're so close, we feel each other's pain.
The voluptuous beauty notices Charlie's soaked crotch. He winks...
See what you do to me, baby.
Just then, the spry HELEN McDOLE, 60s, emerges from the mansion.  She approaches Ted and hugs him.
Oh my, he would have been so proud.  You're the spitting image of him.
He never spits, ma'am. Ever. He can't even get a good hocker going. I've tried to teach him. It comes from the diaphragm.
(sharply; to Charlie) You're on the next plane home.
(emotional embrace) I'm Helen McDole.  Your father's executive secretary.

Ted takes a seat at the spacious conference table.  Helen sits on his right. Charlie sits on his left.   Zukerman and two other IMPATIENT ATTORNEYS wait at the he of the table.  Finally Zukerman checks his watch and rise
We're running out of time. The kid's here. We don't need HIM.
Perhaps we could be patient for just a moment or two longer?
They all watch a WALL CLOCK. Seconds pass, slowly, slowly Then suddenly Zukerman rises.
What did the doctor say to the nurse as they watched something black and white and red in a blender? (a wry smile) No more patients.
Very dramatically, Zukerman slides a copy of "Heaven" magazine down the conference table. Right to Ted.
Are you familiar with "Heaven?"
I'm seventeen. I know it like the back of my hand.
Your fathered owned the entire "Heaven" empire.  You own it now. Any questions?
Ted's stunned, speechless. Charlie gawks.
Everything?  The publishing division, the real estate holdings, the retail outlets, the theme parks?
As far as the eye can see.

Zukerman presses a remote control.  A wall panel slides o to reveal a large monitor which springs to life.  On the screen is a striking couple.  Ted'S BIOLOGICAL PARENTS.  HEATHER and TOM DEEDS. Heather, stunningly sexy and overflowing from her gold sequined halter top. Tom, very handsome in a Vegas showman sort of way.
Oh, sweetheart! We wish we could be right there to hug the living daylights out of you!
But if you're watching this, then it means we bit the dust.
But don't worry...we'll be in heaven. The REAL heaven, I mean. Not that heaven is an actual place, but more like a state of being. Or not being. Who knows. Maybe we know now.
If you're anything like yours truly, then you probably figure we didn't want you when you were born, so who cares if we're dead? Am I right?
Ted looks guilty. This is too weird.
But we did want you. It's just that you don't always get to keep what you want. We knew you needed a real mom and dad.
We had no idea the nudie magazine we started in the garage would turn into all this.
Heather holds up the first issue of "Heaven." She's on th cover, wearing nothing but a halo. She looks almost exact the same today, with a few extra nips and tucks.
Can you believe that was me?
Before we knew it, we created the most popular men's magazine in the entire nation. The rest is history.
So here we are. Dead. But we never want you to want for anything. That is, we want you to have everything.
Everything.
Heather leans forward and blows a kiss into the camera. H strongest assets spilling forward.
We love you, Ted. We always did. We always will.
Charlie's practically slobbering. He elbows Ted.
I can't believe that's your mother. We're talking babe-a-licious chub fest, right here in the 501's.
Perv.
At that moment, the doors burst open. WILLIAM G. DEEDS (U BILLY) sails into the room.  Handsome in an unconventiona way, he exudes passion and eccentricity.
I'm so terribly sorry.  Am I too late?
Ah, Mr. Deeds. You're just in time to congratulate your nephew. He inherited the empire.
(a broad smile) Every morsel of it?
It would appear so.
Uncle Billy hugs Ted with great enthusiasm.
Smashing!  Welcome to the family, Ted. You are going to breathe some new life into this place. You are going to set the world on fire! You are going to...call me Uncle Billy? Please?
(awkwardly) Uh, sure. Uncle Billy.
I have only one concern...
Ted waits. Swept up by Uncle Billy's spirit.
You do like girls, don't you?
Of course I like girls.
A lot? I mean, a whole lot?
As much as possible.
You're sure?
(to the rescue) He likes them with the unbridled enthusiasm of a seventeen-year-old virgin who's been making mental beef jerky since he saw the bevy of tender young skirt steaks at his new hacienda.
Uncle Billy grins broadly.
That's my boy!
Uncle Billy leads Ted and Charlie through the cavernous r Sexy, semi-clad oil paintings of Ted's biological mother adorn the walls.
The parties are held in here when the weather dips below seventy. Which is seldom.
Seldom? No kidding?
You said parties but you meant ORGIES, right? (to Ted; quietly) Stick with me. I know their codes.
Uncle Billy winks at Ted.
The orgies, exactly. Take a deep breath. You can smell it. Pure sexuality, oozing from the walls.
Charlie takes a deep breath. Uncle Billy and Ted share a conspiratorial smirk.
The epitome of every boy's dream arcade.  Everything from classic pinball machines to the most high tech virtual reality game that has yet to hit the market.  Charlie sha his head in amazement.
Naked girls, wild sex, video games. No wonder it's called "Heaven."
This is a fun place...but we don't usually come here until after the orgies.
(playing along) Ah, in other words, this is the apres-orgy salon?
Indeed it is. During the day, visitors prefer to be outside, au naturel. As it were.
Charlie continues to gawk. Ted's equally impressed but holding it together.

Uncle Billy leads Ted and Charlie by the indoor pool whic decorated like a tropical pond, complete with exotic vegetation, lava rocks, and a waterfall.  They pass throu cave-like entrance and find themselves...

...coming out by another spectacular waterfall. Which separates the indoor and outdoor pools. Numerous BEAUTIFU WOMEN swim, chat, play water polo. Some topless, some mig as well be.  The boys watch in awe as one woman rubs loti on another woman's back.
Hello, girls! Have you met Ted?
The women wave, ad-libbing warm greetings. Charlie leans towards Ted, confiding...
This is like my every wet dream come true.  I don't even care that you're here, too, bro.
Be cool. Fake it if you have to.
Good advice, Ted. You have your father's instincts.
"His father." The words sound so strange. He never even m the guy.
Just remember, you're not the man you were a day ago. And these girls, let's just say they'd be eager to please you.
Ted gulps. It's hard to believe this is real.
I wonder how many of them will be at the orgy tonight?
This isn't some 80's porno film, you dip shit. There are no wild sex orgies.
Oh. Well. Maybe not yet.

You're so twitterpated you don't even see the miner's hat and the pickax.
You're implying she's, what, a gold digger?
Julie shrugs. Isn't it obvious?
Charlie's right. Jealousy is so unattractive.
Second only to unbridled, narcissistic conceit.
(whining) Why can't you be nice to me?
You've got enough people kissing your ass.
Ginger returns with a rose.
Here you go, cutie patootie. Rich guys always wear flowers.
Julie gives Ted a look. See what I mean.
Jay Leno seems charmed.  Ted behaves as if he does this e day. The rose from Ginger is pinned to his lapel.
How are the hometown folks treating you, back in Xenia?
Well, Jay. They've been exceptionally supportive.
Are they hitting you up for donations? Asking you to sponsor the local quilting bee?
Audience LAUGHS.
I'm no stranger to the notion of philanthropy. Andrew Carnegie has long been one of my idols.
What about the future? You planning to rock the boat at all? Stir things up in "Heaven?"
Ted's so smooth. We know it's still HIM under all that Armani, but it sure does make him LOOK different.
Matter of fact, Jay, my uncle and I are planning to rethink the magazine. To expand the traditional western notions of "beauty."
I see, so you'd be open to little ladies from Pasadena, who want to show you their knickers?
Matter of fact, Jay, I'm planning a pictorial focusing on the women of my hometown, "The Girls of Xenia." Just to show my appreciation.
Julie looks thoroughly disgusted.
The Girls of Xenia? Jesus.
Now you're talking. What did Andrew Carnegie ever do? Open a couple of libraries? BOR-ING.
A Cocker Spaniel, POOCHIE, sits under a breakfast table, holding a newspaper in his snout.
Poochie?  Where's my poochie? Where is she?

MRS. MERKIN, dressed in a bathrobe and curlers, prepares breakfast.  Their beautiful college-aged daughter, JUDY, cereal at the table, while flipping through a glamour magazine. Principal Merkin enters. Ready for work. Wife a daughter don't even look up.
Is my Poochie in here?
Principal Merkin pretends to look for the dog in the cupboard. This is obviously a daily ritual.
Is she in here?  No.  Where on earth could she be?
He looks under the table.
There's my Poochie!  There's my girl!
The dog leaps into his arms.  Principal Merkin grabs the paper as Poochie starts to lick his face.
Poochie loves Daddy, doesn't she?
Breakfast is getting cold.
Thank you, dear.
No dogs at the table.
I know, dear.
Principal Merkin places the dog on the ground, takes a se and bites into a breakfast sausage.  He opens the paper a is confronted by a full page ad.
"GIRLS OF XENIA, GO STRAIGHT TO HEAVEN!"  Details follow. How, when, where to apply.

Who chokes on his sausage. Clutches his throat. Signaling his wife and daughter. "Help me!" Judy looks up, grossed Mrs. Merkin attempts the Heimlich Maneuver. Rather ineptl Principal Merkin turns red, blue, purple. Finally the pie of sausage flies out of his mouth, past Judy. Poochie cat it in mid-flight.
(weakly) Thatta girl.
Principal Merkin drives to work, humming along to Liza Minelli's "New York, New York." The song comes to an end a radio spot begins...
How many times have people told you, "Jeepers, you look swell naked!" Well now's your chance to go straight to "Heaven!"
Principal Merkin tries to change the station. But the ad seems to be on every station...
Come on down for "The Girls of Xenia" pictorial. Let's show the nation our cows aren't the only ones with great udders.
Students hover at the bulletin board, reading a poster advertising the "Heaven" auditions.  Principal Merkin pus through the crowd and tears the poster off the board.  Completely incensed.

Hundreds of Xenia CITIZENS have gathered for this meeting Principal Merkin stands in front of the five members of t city council who sit at a U-shaped table.  He holds up "Heaven" magazine. Preaching with an evangelical passion.

This, my friends, this is not "Heaven." This flesh rag is a one way ticket to hell! We must voice our outrage! To remain passive in the eye of the devil is like inviting him to a pot luck in your own backyard and asking him to bring the three-bean salad!
His supporters murmur agreement.
For the sake of this community, and its impressionable young minds, I propose this publication be banned from our city!
His POSSE of supporters APPLAUD. His opponents GROAN. Ted slouches nearby.  A lawyer next to him.  The MAYOR bangs gavel and the commotion settles.
Thank you for that long-winded but impassioned speech, Mr. Merkin. I hope you can cut to the chase, Ted.
Principal Merkin takes his seat. Ted rises. Playing the b shot lawyer. Julie sits in the crowd, taking notes.
With all due respect to Merk, he doesn't have to read my magazine. But he has no right to stop others. (to Principal Merkin) Ever hear of the First Amendment?
(rising; an outburst) We cannot afford free speech if it excises the moral fiber of this community!

If that were true, this would be one seriously constipated town. Most guys in Xenia have been looking at naked girls in "Heaven" since they were old enough to figure out their dads hide it under the mattress.
A bit of an UPROAR from the crowd. WOMEN eye their HUSBAN suspiciously. Julie makes a point...
Isn't it true, Principal Merkin, that you only care now because "Heaven" is suddenly too close to home?
Indeed it is, Miss Conroy! I make no bones about it! "Heaven" has gone too far!
MR. NEEDLEMAN, another angry man from Principal Merkin's posse, jumps on the bandwagon.
Principal Merkin is right! We can't let "Heaven" violate our own daughters, wives, sisters, mothers, girlfriends, aunts...
Helen motions to Ted. He quickly locates a page in the re she prepared for him. He handles this like a pro...

I wouldn't want to name names, Mr. Needleman, or cause any undue embarrassment. But many members of this community have been loyal "Heaven" readers for the better part of the last two decades. Not to mention certain charter subscribers who have developed a voracious appetite for our video library as well. I don't suppose, "Courtney Leaves The Convent" rings a bell to anyone?
Mr. Needleman dissolves into his seat. Half the men in th audience seem to evaporate.
Mr. Nelson, you are Beelzebub's henchman! You are single-handedly destroying the integrity of our community, and I will not have it!  I'll gather signatures. I'll petition the courts.
(sheepishly) You do what you have to do, Dick. But if there's a man among us who doesn't like to steal a look at some pretty titty once in a while, let him cast the first stone.
The room is suddenly SILENT. Principal Merkin gives the M a hard look.  Merkin's face contorts in SLOW MO as he proclaims...
I. AM. THAT. MAN.
Holding a stack of flyers, Charlie chats with Judy, Merki college-aged daughter.
You're like a centerfold waiting to happen. And let me assure you, I have some serious pull with the publisher.
Judy smiles fetchingly. Stashing Charlie's "Heaven" flyer her backpack. Her father suddenly appears.
What the hell are you doing?
I'm an adult. I can do whatever I want.
My roof, my rules, young lady.
He grabs her arm while knocking the stack of flyers out o Charlie's hands.  As Principal Merkin drags her away, Jud smiles back at Charlie.  He winks.
Send us a picture, sugar.  We'll get back to you.
The stack of flyers FLOATS over the railing and onto the ground floor, just as a group of LOVELY YOUNG WOMEN enter the building lobby. They excitedly reach for the flyers.

A line of BEAUTIFUL WOMEN - all shapes and sizes - snakes around the block and into a doorway.  The women are dress to impress, in very skimpy clothing. Ted pulls up in his convertible Ferrari. The women shout greetings as Ted hea for the door.
We follow Ted as he dashes up the stairs, along the line women, towards an office.
(greeting the women) Hello there...Looking great...Very nice.
Charlie looks frazzled.
You're late, bro!
Sorry. Ginger got a little, you know, enthusiastic.
You'll never believe who's in there.
It better not be my Aunt Trudy.
They enter...
A YOUNG WOMAN sits with her back to the door.
Sorry to keep you waiting...
The woman turns towards Ted, revealing herself to be Chri Malone.  Ted is momentarily stunned.
Hi, Teddy Bear.
Christy?  You want to be in "Heaven?"
I turned eighteen over spring break. I'm eligible.
Ted doesn't know what to say. Charlie's equally stunned.  Hell, it seems, has frozen over.
I feel like I've just been hit by a Mack truck.
With a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.
Highly modified since the last time we saw it. A large fl screen hangs on the wall.   A high tech computer system f video conferences dominates the room.  Ted speaks with Un Billy and Helen.
So far, so good. Some of them have real Angel potential.
Really? So I'm doing OK?
We're impressed but not surprised, Ted. You have your father's impeccable judgment.
Dad passes the partially open door. Overhearing. He stops
My father must've been amazing.
He was in a league of his own.
Suddenly Ted feels his dad's presence, behind him.
Sorry I--
It's okay. You need me?
(holding a list) Your mom said you've been ignoring your chores.
Ted takes the list.  Gives it a cursory glance. Nods to h dad, as if dismissing him.
No problem, consider it done. (to Uncle Billy) I had this idea of shooting on location. Outdoors, you know? Maybe at some famous Xenia landmarks.  You think that would be a problem?
We'll send you the release forms, Ted. Our staffers will help in any way they can.
You're the Titan of Tushies, the General of Jism.  Don't you forget it, Ted-baby.
Ted laughs. Completely ignoring his dad. Who backs out of room. Unnoticed. Neglected. Hurt.

Mom drives up to the house.  She stares, aghast. There are tall, beautiful, ANGELS everywhere.  One cuts t grass.  Another pulls weeds. Two others on the roof, clea gutters. Still others wash the car...with Jimmy handling the water hose. Drenching the women, more than the car. Shrieks and giggles all around. Neighbors gawk. Ted's dad guiltily enjoys the view, but quickly rushes to wife. She gets out of her car and steadies herself on his arm.
Ted stands on an ottoman as a TAILOR fits him for a prom tuxedo. He towers over his parents who try to talk to him feel for them. They've lost control of their kid.
You have to understand. This was a big shock, for all of us. One minute you're our little boy, of whom we could not be more proud. The next minute you're the owner of this whole pornographic empire.
But that doesn't make you the boss of everything, son.
Don't you see how your self involvement and lack of humility are affecting the whole family?
Ted looks down at them, literally.
I paid off the mortgage! I ordered that Winnebago you always wanted! Now you're ashamed of me?
You ordered a Winnebago?
Mom gives Dad a look. Stick to the script. Don't be swaye presents.
We're not ashamed of you, Teddy. We don't approve of the magazine or the models or the so-called "flesh parties" you attend. But we can get past all that.
We miss you. We miss our son.
We miss our family.
I promised I'd finish high school and that's what I'm doing. What more do you want from me?
Dad glances at Mom, hesitant.  She nods, giving him the courage to continue.
We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.
We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.
Ted laughs.
THAT is your dream, not mine. My dream is so far beyond anything YOU PEOPLE could even imagine.
Watch your tone, mister.
Why don't you just admit what this is really all about? I'm not your real kid and you can't control me anymore.
Mom and Dad look stricken. Ted doesn't know when to stop.

No wonder I was so bored. No wonder I hated this one-horse cow town. I come from talented people who took chances and dared to imagine a life without limits! I was never meant to be raised by...GROCERS.
Ted storms away, unintentionally CRASHING into a TREASURE FAMILY PHOTO on the end table. The frame shatters into smithereens. Breaking Mom and Dad's hearts. STUNNED SILEN hangs heavy in the room.

Prom night.  Couples slow dance to a Marilyn Manson clone singing a rock version of "Precious and Few." Principal Merkin watches on the sidelines.  Surprisingly calm. Suspiciously happy. Ted caresses Ginger's bare back as they dance together. H head nestled against her breasts. Not a care in the world He spots Charlie on the dance floor. Making out with one his dates, the IDENTICAL TAYLOR TRIPLETS, while the other patiently wait their turn.
Teddy? I was thinking.
Hmmm?
After graduation...maybe we could go away together?
Whatever you want.
WE notice Christy Malone dancing with her FOOTBALL CAPTAI DATE. The perfect male specimen. Christy gives Ted a disappointed, longing gaze. But he's oblivious.
I bet St. Tropez in July would be paradise. For a honeymoon.
Suddenly a FLASH blinds them. It's Julie Conroy, doing he job.  Following her subject.
(snapping) You could have warned us.
Oops, sorry. Warning: You've got lipstick on your teeth.

Julie flashes the camera again. Capturing Ginger's panick expression. We notice that Julie looks alluring in a deep purple strapless gown. Not so glamorous as Ginger, but fa more appealing and natural.
Wow...you clean up nice.
Put your eyeballs back in your head, William Randolph. I'm on assignment. A girl has to fit in.
Ginger seems testy and jealous. Her true colors emerging.
Teddy, I thought we were having a moment here.
Of course we were.
Suddenly the music dies.  Everyone turns to the stage whe Principal Merkin stands proudly. Holding a power cord.

I apologize for interrupting the festivities, but I have some good news. I've been reviewing the rules and regulations set forth by the superintendent of schools. And it seems quite clear... (reading from manual) "Minors may not be accompanied to school functions by adults unless they are their parents or legal guardians."
A spotlight suddenly finds Ted and Charlie's beautiful da
So long, ladies. Prom's over.
The crowd boos, hisses.
Honestly, Merk. It's like you were never seventeen and the head of a media empire.
Rules are rules.
Come on, it's our only senior prom.
Deaf ears, Mr. Nelson. I answer to a higher power.
Charlie steps in like a hostage negotiator.
Here's the deal, Merk.  Forget the "rules and regulations" malarkey and we'll give you seven minutes in heaven with the Taylor Triplets.
Out! Now!
Ted realizes his high school reputation is at stake. He s up on stage. Approaches Principal Merkin. Takes out his wallet.
What's your price, Merk? How much will it cost to make you go bye bye?
The crowd CHEERS.
You're crossing the line, Mr. Nelson.
A statue in front of city hall, dedicated to Principal Dick Merkin?
I'm warning you.
A new pediatric wing at the hospital? A presidential campaign? Name it. Anything.
Principal Merkin trembles from the sheer temptation of it Yet he could never succumb in front of so many witnesses. has to maintain his dignity...
That's it! You're out of here!
From nowhere, a flock of beefy SECURITY GUARDS emerge to remove Ted & Co.
Good-bye, Mr. Nelson.  Have a pleasant evening.
The Marilyn Manson clone is rapidly whisked away, and replaced by six GEEZERS in powder blue tuxedoes. As Security Guards carry them away...
Ted! Do something!
(restrained) What do you want me to do?
This is humiliating. We're being ejected from a prom!
Hang in there, I'll think of something.
As they reach the doors...
Well?
I guess...I don't know...I guess we should leave if we're not wanted.
I hear you, bro. We're Angus men in a ground round town.
This is what I get for playing den mother in "Romper Room." Take me to the airport, Charlie!
Why don't you just hitch a ride on the horse you rode in on?
Ginger storms away in an angry huff.
(calling after her) Don't forget your broom!
Ted experiences a moment of loss.
I thought I loved her.
Chicks are like buses. If you miss one, don't sweat it. There's another coming 'round the corner.
One of the Taylor Triplets bats her lashes at Ted.
(whispering to Ted) Take your pick. They're IDENTICAL.
Ted grins broadly. He turns and SHOUTS to his classmates.
Everybody, listen up! This prom sucks!  Let's party at my place!
Responses are mixed. Some cheer, some are undecided. Unti the new band starts playing, "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round t Old Oak Tree." And EVERYONE RUSHES for the exit, followin Ted.
A muzak version of "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree," continues.  A PIZZA DELIVERY GUY watches the numbe rise to the penthouse.  Suddenly the doors open to reveal

All four penthouse suites have been rented by Ted.  It's party central. Very wild.  Quickly growing out of control Kids dance, play drinking games, Spin the Bottle, and generally trash the place. The pizza delivery guy wheels a dolly with a huge stack o pizzas into the party, only to be attacked by the prom-go like starving beasts. Grabbing the pizzas.  Devouring the hungrily.

Ted, Charlie, the Taylor Triplets and several buddies lou around, drunkenly watching THE HOME SHOPPING CHANNEL on T big screen TV.  A tacky CERAMIC GNOME rotates on the scre Ted swigs Dom Perignon straight from the bottle. He shout orders into his cell phone...
Hell yes, all hundred and seventeen of 'em!
No, leave one. Somebody's grandmother might want one.
And while you're at it, I'll take ten dozen of those puppies with the springy heads.
I love those springy head puppies!
Ted looks up as the elevator doors open.  Principal Merki has arrived. Ted confronts him...
You kicked us off your turf, Merk.  Don't rain on our parade.
Mr. Nelson, you disappoint me. First you break our school board rules. Then you break the law.
What law, Merk? Having fun? Letting down our hair on prom night?
Our state has a zero tolerance policy for underage drinking.
You called the cops on us?
Alcohol does horrible things to a developing young mind.
Suddenly the whole XENIA POLICE FORCE appears, in full ri gear.  The party's over.  Everyone runs for the stairs. gives Principal Merkin a spiteful look and joins the mass exodus.

Drunken teenagers pour out of the building.  Dashing for their cars and limos.  Ted's among them.  Suddenly he's c off by a Harley that stops right in front of him.  It's Julie.  Still in her purple strapless prom dress. With a black motorcycle jacket over it.
Need a lift?
Ted jumps on, wrapping his arms around her waist. Julie t off.
Julie maneuvers the nighttime streets of Xenia, taking of down a country road.
Where are we going?
To the best hiding place in the world.
Now we understand. Julie's family comes from major bucks. yard is massive. And resting in a sprawling oak tree is t best hiding place in the world.
A cozy oasis. Books everywhere.  A whole series of flashlights hang upside down like lanterns. Giving the tr house a warm glow.
I can't believe your dad built this for you.
He didn't. He had it built.
Whatever.
Not "whatever."  It's two different things.
He cared enough to want you to have it.
He phoned it in.
I see.
I doubt it.
Now it makes sense, the whole neo Bohemian, down with hypocrisy, fight the power crap. You're a poor little rich girl.
The ozone must be fully depleted on Planet Ted.
You think my dad would have been like that if I knew him? You think he would have bought me a stadium, instead of teaching me how to play ball?
Your dad taught you everything.
I mean my father.
A father is nothing but sperm, Ted. It takes a real man to be a dad.
It's all so complicated.
It's incredibly simple.
I feel like I'm being drawn and quartered. Like every part of me is being pushed and pulled and tugged in a different direction.
Eventually you'll let go.
And then what?
Then you'll see who's really holding on to you.
You're amazing.
I know.
Even when you infuriate me, I still want to kiss you.
But you never do.
If we were a team, we could do anything. I mean, anything.
Julie's eyes narrow. She should have known.
Cut to the chase, William Randolph.  Your audience is way ahead of you.
In a word: MERK. EXPOSED.
That's two words. And I'm out of the "exposed" business, remember? I need to graduate. Besides, Merk's a boy scout.
There's gotta be something. We have to dig deeper.
You forget, I dislike YOU at least as much as him.
He shut down your paper!  You're stuck writing articles about swap meets and raffles and PTA brunches!
He's right, but...
A good journalist can take lemons and make lemonade. I'm honing my craft.
Then you won't mind covering that watermelon seed spitting contest next week...
Julie groans.

Dressed in a old fashioned barber costume, complete with handle bar mustache, Principal Merkin sings as part of a BARBER SHOP QUARTET. The senior citizens clap enthusiastically. Ted and Julie peek through a crack in the doorway. Disappointment on their faces.
Principal Merkin pours soup into the bowl of a shabbily dressed HOMELESS MAN. Julie shoots Ted an "I told you so" look.
Principal Merkin supervises a crew of kindergarten CHILDR cleaning up the roadside litter. Julie and Ted watch from
See what I mean. He's squeaky clean. He makes Gandhi look like a war monger.
Ted steels himself. Somehow, they'll get him.

In the golden light of sunset, MOLLY, a stunning "Xenia Girl," stands on the stairs that curve up around a huge w tower that overlooks the city.  Her loose spring dress billows in the wind. Held on by only one button. Exposing quick glimpses that she isn't wearing a bra.  An ASSISTANT holds a portable strobe, attached to a reflector.  Charlie shoots with his Nikon.  Motor drive whirling.
I have a great idea.  Let's lose the last button.

Molly grins. Then unbuttons. We hear a round of "oohs" fr below.  Ted glances down, where... Hundreds of binoculars, cameras, and camcorders are poise the scene.  Men of all ages are milling around, gawking, focusing their long lenses.  Women are conspicuously abse Except for the gaggle of hardcore FEMINISTS with their placards, denouncing "Heaven." One Feminist approaches the Mayor.
The city tower belongs to the city, not to some pornographer.
The library also belongs to the city.  And guess what?  It's going to have a new Ted Nelson wing with  three thousand children's books.

The Feminist tries to respond, but a helicopter swoops overhead, drowning out her words. The helicopter rises to level of the photo shoot where the door slides open.  And just when we think it must have been hired by some hard c fans who wanted a closer look, we find Principal Merkin frowning as he barks through a bullhorn.
You should be ashamed, young lady!  Your body is a sacred temple!

Molly flashes him. Principal Merkin averts his eyes.  Mis the sight of Molly's dress being blown off her body by th chopper's prop wash.  The spectators below APPLAUD.  They watch in amazement as her dress floats down to them.
Young lady, I will pray for god's mercy upon your soul.
Don't bother, Merk! I'm already going to "Heaven!"
(to Charlie) Get them together.
(eyes lighting up) Brilliant!  Molly, give me all you've got.  For Merk.
Molly gets the idea.  She poses provocatively towards Principal Merkin, who suddenly realizes he's in a compromising position.
Stop that, stop that this instant!
But Molly pulls off her panties and flings them at him.
Uncle Billy chortles, his image glowing on a large flat screen monitor that hangs on the wall.  Ted leans back in chair.
I never saw anybody turn so many shades of red.
I can't wait to see the pictures.
It was incredible. The light, the crowd, everything.
Uncle Billy grins proudly at Ted.
Such enthusiasm. Have I told you lately how proud I am of you?
Seriously? I'm doing all right?
You're taking this bull of an empire by the horns, but you're still keeping your small town values. You're not letting all this "stuff" spoil you.
Ted knows it's not true. He looks guilty.
I owe it all to you. Without your help I'd be lost.
I wish I knew you years ago, when my brother was alive. I wish he never gave you up.
Yeah, well, like my Grandpa used to say...you can't change your Christmas past, but you sure can exchange your Christmas presents.
Uncle Billy forces a laugh.
Why don't you come to town this weekend? We could play some golf, chase some skirts.
Ted smiles at the appealing offer.
I'd love to, but I really need to crack the books.  Final exams are coming up and I've been slacking.
You're right. I should work, too. Our first issue together is almost ready to print.
Thanks, Uncle Billy. Thanks for everything.
You're a great kid. Don't you forget it.
With that, he's gone. The room is completely silent. And is completely alone. UNTIL the doorbell CHIMES.
Ted opens the door. It's Jimmy, with his shiny new bike.
James, what are you doing here?
You can call me Jimmy again. Sheryl Petersen said James sounds too pretentious.
Sheryl Petersen is, what, nine years old, what does she know?
She knew exactly where you were staying, which you neglected to tell me, your own brother.
It's really late...do your parents know where you are?
Mom and Dad think I'm tucked safely in bed and that's all they need to know. Will this discussion be continuing in the hallway, or somewhere slightly more inviting?
Jimmy seems impressed by the opulence. He takes off his b helmet, looks around.
Impressive. This is bigger than our whole house.
Most places are, Jimmy.
They say money can't buy happiness but this is a reasonably good facsimile.
So, what brings you here at his hour?
My new bike.
Very funny.
I came to ask permission to take custody of your room.
My room?
Better view, more spacious, new carpet. It's a no-brainer.
It's not up to me.
Mom and Dad said it's yours. They seem to think you're coming home.
You can have it, then. I'm not going back there.
Jimmy whips out a piece of paper from his pocket.
If you could just sign right there.
You want it in writing?
Just a formality.
Ted signs. Jimmy squirrels away the paper, excitedly. Sta to zip up his wind breaker.
That's it? I mean, you don't want to order room service or anything? We could play games and watch movies and stuff.
Are you kidding? Mom and Dad discover I'm gone and I'll be doing hard time.
Are they okay?
Aside from the fact that Mom's eyes are nearly swollen shut from crying and Dad spends all his time under the car trying to fix stuff that isn't broken, things couldn't be better.
I miss them, too.
You can't come back. That is, you can, but your things will be in the room you currently think of as mine.
You're a peach.
Funny you should say that. My Grandfather was a peach farmer.
Ouch. For the first time, that really smarts.
He was my Grandfather, too.
I meant biologically.
That's a crappy thing to say.
Look Ted. I'm cool with everything. You've long been dissatisfied with our mediocre little town. You've always had an itch for the good life. I'm happy for you. This couldn't happen to a nicer guy.
Ted listens.

But just for the record, my Mom is a kick-ass schoolteacher and my Dad is the best damn auto mechanic this side of the Himalayas. You seem to have forgotten they opened Nelson's FAMILY Market so they could build something permanent, a legacy, for us. Their kids.
I didn't forget.
You ever look down on them again and call them "grocers" like it's a dirty word, and you'll be sucking your filet mignon through a straw for six to eight weeks. Got it?
Ted's stunned. Talk about tough love.
Loud and clear.
Suddenly the phone rings. Ted sheepishly explains...
That's probably my office.
Well? Where the hell are you?
He's on the move?
I got an anonymous tip and an address in Cincinnati.
Let's do it.
Ted hangs up the phone.  Looks around.  Jimmy's gone. But SHINY NEW BIKE is left behind.
Not much of a place. A middle-aged TORCH SINGER croons "M ROMANCE."  Ted and Julie find their way to corner table. Keeping an eye out for Principal Merkin.
I don't know. This place seems pretty tame.
You expected whips, chains, Merk being cattle-prodded by some dominatrix in a leather hood?
At least it's not another 4-H meeting or a Big Brother barbecue.
Amen to that.
Their heads are very close together. A conspiratorial tet tete.
Look at us. It's one o'clock in the morning, on a school night. We're in a smoky nightclub, hoping to catch our principal with some big city tart.
I'm trembling with excitement.
That has more to do with your proximity to me.
(playing along) My desire betrays me, like goosebumps on my flesh.
I have a bit of a goosebump fetish. Not many people know that.
I figured you for more of a hairy armpit guy.
Shoes, if you want to know the truth. Shoes are my thing.
Wearing them?  Or humping them?
My fantasy is a totally naked woman, wearing nothing but a Timex and suede clogs.
That's refreshingly deviant.
What about you?
I'm very aural.
Tell me more.
Sounds, voices, music, humming. All of it can turn me on, or off, like a switch.
(feigning a deep voice) I see.
I had a Portuguese boyfriend who could read the phone book and melt me.
(jealous) A Portuguese boyfriend. Sounds very "Cosmo."
You live and learn. I realized the most important thing to me, above all, is trust.
Turned out to be a scoundrel, eh?  I saw that one coming.
You lose trust in someone and it's over, done, gone, forever.
At that moment, the TORCH SINGER begins crooning "PEOPLE.
Do you trust me, Julie?
Not a chance.
Come on.
Trust is something you earn, over time. You don't just inherit it overnight like a gazillion dollar empire.
Ted leans even closer. Looking into her eyes. Using his voice. Being as aurally seductive as he can.
I want you to trust me.
Maybe someday.
Julie, I'll tell you something that is the god's honest truth. I've seen a lot of really beautiful girls. I mean a lot. But none of them make me feel like you do.
That's hard to believe.
But absolutely true.
Ted moves closer.  Julie doesn't move away.  The SINGER s to be performing just for them.
..."A feeling deep in your soul/Says you were half, now you're whole..."
Just as Ted and Julie are about to kiss, Julie's eyes wid She grabs Ted's hand. Simultaneously, they turn towards T SINGER...
OH. MY. GOD.

It's the Mother Lode!  That's not just any middle-aged to singer. That's Principal Merkin.  Dressed in drag as Barb Streisand. And doing a mighty fine job of it. Ted pulls out his camera and fires away. Blinded by the s lights, Principal Merkin sings and vogues glamorously. He no idea his secret is out.

Ted and Julie rush down the street in the rain, giggling, totally euphoric. They stop to catch their breath. Their clothes are drenched, but they couldn't care less. In no they've got their arms wrapped around one another, kissin and laughing.
We just found the ULTIMATE centerfold for "The Girls of Xenia!"
Suddenly Julie sobers, pulls away.
I have to be honest with you, Ted. I really despise "The Girls of Xenia."
I know, their small town mentality can be maddening.
I mean your pictorial. It bothers me, profoundly.
Aw Julie, it's my job. It's like being a doctor.
Julie eyes him skeptically.
You're telling me you don't get aroused by a roomful of naked breasts.
You've seen one naked breast, you've seem them all.
Which explains the continued success of "Heaven" for how many decades?
You're quick. I like that.
You think you're working with chimps here?
The thing is, I made a commitment. I said I'd do it and I have to keep my word.
Keeping your word is something I can actually respect, Ted.

head_text.subj: TREMBLING HANDS, STRUGGLING TO LOAD A ROLL OF FILM INTO A

text: Ted closes the back of his camera. Takes a deep breath. A forces a confident smile. He then peers into the...
Where Christy Malone limbers up.  Stretching her leg agai the wall. Wearing her sexy cheerleader uniform.
I thought I'd be nervous, but you sure know how to make a girl feel relaxed, Teddy Bear.
I do? I mean, yeah, I do.
I have to admit, I am so totally turned on. We should do it. Now.
Do it?
You know...take the pictures?

Christy does her warm-up contortionist poses for Ted.  Clothes still on.  As reflectors bounce strobes into the shower area. Years of being a merciless tease, paying off right here a now. Christy knows how to make love to the camera.
I remember the first time you walked into Mrs. Temple's class in 2nd grade. Blue gingham dress. Blond ponytail.
Which you pulled, hard!
That was code for "I like you."
Christy giggles.
Wanna unzip me?
Ted slowly unzips Christy's top, catching a glimpse of he long, sensuous back. She resumes posing. Flashing a bare shoulder.  A coy look. She doesn't need direction. She's natural.
Remember dress up day?  You and Charlie lifting skirts during recess.
I miss those days, when schoolyard sexual harassment was without consequence.
Things change. Now I'm taking off my clothes...all by myself.
Christy slips off her cheerleader top. Lowers her skirt. Flings it aside. She's wearing only panties the size of a Band-aid. Ted is mute. Staring at her perfect body.
Well?
You have changed since second grade.
I mean, what do you think?
You expect me to think at a time like this? There isn't a drop of blood in my brain.
Oh, Teddy Bear, you're funny.

Ted steps out of the shower.  Out of Christy's sight, he squirms in his jeans. Trying to hide his enthusiasm. MUSIC suddenly seems to come from nowhere. Nine Inch Nail "I Want to Fuck You Like An Animal."
(sotto) God help me.
Ted steps back into the shower.  Christy rubs an ice cube her left nipple.
I heard they do this on photo shoots.  Wanna to do the other one?
She tosses him the ice cube. He fumbles. It lands on the floor.
You're doing just fine, Christy. Believe me.
Then I'm ready when you are.

Ted looks through the lens. We can see him trembling.  Mu blasts as Ted's camera burns through film.  They're both getting into it.  Water pulsating over her body. Steam rising.  Christy begins lathering her breasts.
I was always too shy to admit how much I liked you.
Come on, I was hamburger. You were porterhouse.
Maybe on the outside. But inside, deep down, I've always been dripping with special sauces.  (she smiles, sexily) Are you hungry?
Is he hungry. He's been working up this appetite for ten years. He can barely contain himself.
God, you are so hot.
Then you better get in the water, before you get burned.
Ted calls her bluff. He sets aside his camera. Walks righ into the water. Through the steam.  Toward Christy. She w a leg around him, sucking face, wanting more.
You and me, finally. This will be so fantastic, Teddy Bear. Trust me.
Suddenly Ted stops. Remembering what Julie said about tru
I'm sorry, Christy. I've been crazy about you forever, and this is definitely a page right out of my palm pilot, but I just can't go through with it.
He turns away, but Christy presses her bare body against back.  Wrapping her hands around his waist. Caressing his chest, his stomach...
Sure you can. You're only human. It's not like you're made of steel. (she lowers her hand) Or ARE you?

Ted and Christy locked in a steamy embrace. Rolling on th floor. Hands, arms, lips, tongues, all in motion. As the shower drenches them. Suddenly, they roll into a pair of legs.  Both look up. steam clears to reveal Julie. Arms crossed. Hurt, but not surprised.
What's up, doc?
She doesn't wait for an explanation. Christy covers herse Ted chases after Julie.
Wait, Julie, wait!
Julie dashes out of the girls' locker room, passing a JANITOR.  Ted follows, dripping water.
I'm sorry, Mr. Ted. She pushed right past me.
(calling after Julie) At least let me explain!
Julie darts into the girls' restroom.  Ted stops at the d Then realizes there is no one else around.  He heads insi
Julie's too proud to let him see her cry. But we can tell she's upset.
Go away, Ted. Just go.
Ted corners her near a row of sinks.

Please believe me. It was just a kiss for old time's sake. I've had a stupid crush on her since I was seven, but I never got closer to her than four feet and then there she was right in front of me, completely naked.

Julie looks at him, pensively. She unzips the back of her summery dress. And lets it fall to the floor. She's completely naked and absolutely gorgeous. Ted gasps. He's been around dozens of naked women by now, this one he can't just gawk at. This one he really cares about.

Being naked is no big deal. It has nothing to do with emotion, nothing to do with love. You can be around all the naked girls you want and you won't be even one step closer to anything meaningful in your life.
She puts on her dress, gracefully. As if nothing happened
See that? You don't know me even one ounce better than you did before. You and your stupid  magazine. I liked you better when you were sweet and kind and human, like the rest of us.
At that moment, Ted's cell phone rings. Julie walks away, leaving Ted completely alone. He answers, lifelessly...
Yes?
We've got a huge problem with the magazine, Ted-baby. Our readers hate it. HATE IT. We need to talk.
Ted walks down the hallway.  Three JOCKS look through the issue of "Heaven." Laughing.  They taunt Ted.
You got a great sense of humor. I love the three hundred pound Eskimo chick.
You like Eskimo pie, Teddy?
I like the African chick with the big lip. You could stash a lot of weed in there. Maybe even a six pack.
Ted's mortified, depressed. Charlie appears next to him w "Heaven" in hand.
Holy stinkers, what were you thinking?
We wanted to challenge the notions of classic beauty. We wanted to showcase women throughout the world.
Next time, make sure you put a barf bag in the centerfold.
Principal Merkin approaches. Also holding "Heaven" in his hand.
Ted, I realize I owe you an apology. You're destroying "Heaven" much faster from the inside than I ever could from the outside. Good job, son.
Ted could not feel worse.
Ted, Uncle Billy, and Helen. Meeting with the HEADS OF VARIOUS DEPARTMENTS.
Our advertisers are wigging out. Half of them are threatening to pull their ads for next month. The other half already did.
It was nothing more than beginner's folly. Tell everyone to lighten up.

It's a little more serious than that, Bill. The stockholders have requested a meeting. They want our guarantee that this will never happen again. (the words pain her) Some of them are even calling for Ted's resignation.
Look, the girls of Xenia are gorgeous, you'll see. Next month we'll be back to normal.
Another disaster like this could sink us. We've got thousands of subscribers requesting refunds.
The kid came up with something that sounded good on paper. Who knew our readers wouldn't dig it?
Ted bristles. THE KID?  The kid came up with something?
We tried to warn you.
Sometimes young people need to make their own mistakes. That's how they learn.
Ted can see that Uncle Billy's playing this out different than he imagined. Giving Ted all the "credit."
(firmly; to Uncle Billy) It won't happen again. It will never happen again.

Ted sits at his father's desk.  Going through paperwork.  Figures.  Charts. Reports. CEO work.  In the b.g., he hea the PLAYFUL SOUNDS of women.  Which distract him. Ted approaches the window and watches a group of girls splashing and playing in the pool. He looks sad. Helen en behind him.  He turns to her.

I always thought I wanted fame and fortune and beautiful women. But sometimes your dreams come true, and they cause you nothing but grief. I just want to chuck everything and sell the stupid magazine. It's not worth the pain.
Helen takes Ted's hand, comfortingly.
Come, let me show you something.
Helen and Ted sit on old trunk. Helen holds a scrapbook i her arms. Explaining to Ted...

Your parents never wanted to interfere with your life, Ted. They knew your Mom and Dad loved you very much. They knew they did the right thing. But that doesn't mean they didn't watch you and miss you, from afar.
You mean they knew who I was?
They kept this scrapbook of your life. It meant the world to them.
We see baby pictures of Ted, taken through the glass of a nursery. A newspaper photo of Ted playing a donkey in a nativity play. And clippings from Ted's high school newspaper.
I wondered about them, for so many years. I wondered if I looked like them, acted like them. I wondered why they gave me up.

Giving you up was the most unselfish thing they ever did. When they founded "Heaven," they wished they could take you back but it was too late. All they could do was build the empire, knowing that someday it would all be yours.
My legacy.
Your parents would be crushed to think you weren't happy with it.
They're not my parents, Helen. My parents are back in Xenia and I hurt them very much.
I understand.
And the girl I love, she hates "Heaven." If I keep it, she'll never respect me.
But how can you respect yourself if you don't?

Ted's parents and Jimmy walk through the front door. They stunned to find a huge 24x36 enlarged family portrait, hanging over the mantle. It's the same picture Ted broke his childish tantrum. Mom and Dad are moved. Even more so when they see Ted. Waiting for them on the couch.  Ted ri Misty eyed.
Everything I am is because of you. Can you ever forgive me?
(hugging him) Oh, Teddy. We missed you so much.
You were always our number one son.
(rolling his eyes) Mom, Dad. This display of unconditional love is appalling.
We are a FAMILY.
A family, need I remind you, that HE ridiculed and left for dead.
Shut your pie hole, Jimmy.
I will not have my boys arguing.
So, when I'm seventeen, can I turn everyone's life upside-down, behave like a total piece of canine excrement, and then wipe the slate clean with a half-baked apology and a Kodak moment?
No!
Which is precisely why I got the rights to my new room IN WRITING.
(to his parents) I need your help.  I'm really in deep shit.
Don't say "shit," honey. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.
Besides, there's no problem too deep or too shitty for us to solve.
Dad reaches for a can of peaches from the shelf.
Son, it's a simple fix. The only difference between my store and that magazine of yours is a bunch of zeros. Now, have I ever told you the story about the can of peaches?
A "Heaven" stockholders' meeting in progress. Uncle Billy stands at the podium.
Ladies, gentlemen. "Heaven" has gone to hell.
Behind him are charts, wall graphs. We quickly realize he a complete and utter turn-coat.

I loved my brother. I stood by his wishes to let his son run the company. A son he never knew. A son that he and his wife gave away at birth. A son who was raised in a world quite different from our own. Nevertheless, I was there for the lad. I guided him as best I could. But he's only seventeen, with a mind of his own and judgment that is, well, frankly, not a chip off the old block. There is only one clear solution... (gesturing to himself) And I think we all know what that is--
--PEACHES! CANNED PEACHES!

Ted bursts into the meeting with his Dad. Holding up a ca peaches. Suddenly hundreds of eyes are upon him. Curious, bewildered.  Ted dashes to the podium, with passion in his soul and fi in his belly.
What are you doing?
My job. Back off, Benedict.
Uncle Billy steps into the shadows as Ted looks out at th crowd. He's petrified. But he takes a deep breath and fin the courage to explain...

The only man I called "Dad" owns a little grocery store in Xenia, Ohio.  He learned a lot of cool stuff from my Grandpa, who was a peach farmer in his day. Grandpa knew the right thing to say in every situation, and it usually involved peaches. My dad's a lot like him. And he taught me, you have to focus on the peachy side of life, not the pits.
Dad's eyes are filled with tears. He's never been so prou

There was a time when canned peaches were the hottest, greatest thing ever invented. It was like a little taste of summer, anytime you wanted. Grocery stores couldn't keep them in stock, they were so popular. And even though other canned fruits like pears, plums, and pineapples have come along, people still need to know they can get their canned peaches, on the same shelf, whenever they want them. It's comforting, you know? It fulfills their expectations.
The stockholders are listening. Uncle Billy grins nervous Unable to believe Ted is pulling this off.

You're probably wondering if there's a point to all this and I guess it's just that I goofed last month. I not only moved the canned peaches, I restocked the shelves with kiwi, guava, and mandarin oranges in heavy syrup. I challenged people's expectations.  And you can't do that to your customers. So, I ask you for one more chance to fix things and give our readers back their canned peaches.
The stockholders APPLAUD enthusiastically, giving Ted a standing ovation. Ted turns to Uncle Billy.
Thanks for teaching me an important lesson. What makes a family is love, not blood.
All is fair in "Heaven," Ted-baby.
That's right. And guess who's the new King of the Unemployment Line.
Aw, come on, kid. Throw me a bone. I'm your uncle for gosh sakes.

Ted looks at pictures. Layouts. Reads copy. Listens to hi staff. He seems confident. In control. Mature beyond his years. The magazine goes to press. In VOICE OVER, we hear Julie, reading the article about Ted that she wrote for t school paper.

"It's easy to fall prey to petty jealousy when considering the young life of Ted Nelson. But how would any of us behave if one day all our dreams came true? Would we handle it half as well? Would we find ourselves making the same mistakes for which we criticize him?"
Someone hands Ted a copy of Julie's article. He reads the last portion of it aloud...
"One can only hope that Ted Nelson will find bigger and better dreams upon which to set his sights as the years pass. And that he will remember, always, where he came from."
Julie opens her front door. Charlie grins. He hands her a copy of "Heaven."
Page three.
Intrigued, she turns to the page.

We see a special dedication, "To Julie, My Partner in Cri With All the Love in the World." Julie's eyes fill with tears. She flips ahead to "The Girls of Xenia" pictorial, only to find-- Principal Merkin. Singing his heart out, in drag as Barbr Streisand. It's a series of shots from the Cincinnati nightclub. Other shots suggestively include him with Moll the foreground, as if they posed together.
Not bad for a hack. He has a future in yellow journalism.
He kicked major ass and you know it.
Principal Merkin drives. The RADIO plays in the b.g. As o song ends, we hear the DJ say...
This one's for you Dick Merkin of Tecumseh High. From all your students. With hugs and kisses.
The voice of Barbra Streisand fills the car.
"People/People who need People/Are the luckiest people in the world."

Principal Merkin pales.  He turns off the radio.  But somehow, he can still hear the song.  As he pulls into th school parking lot, students wave enthusiastically.  He w back tentatively.  Anxiety rising.

Principal Merkin swings open his car door to be greeted b the sound of Barbra singing her heart out through the par lot. Every student's car stereo blasts the song. Students CHEER. Chanting:  "BAR-BRA, BAR-BRA, BAR-BRA!"  Principal Merkin turns crimson.
Graduation caps fall all around. People hugging, laughing overjoyed. Ted searches for Julie, but she's nowhere in sight.
A big graduation party in progress. But Ted sits in the corner, looking sad, dejected. Julie didn't show up. He b it. Jimmy and Charlie approach, with cheering on their mi
Why so melancholy?
You were born naked, wet, and hungry. Now you're hip, handsome, and rich. You are the coxswain on the ship of life.
Eat, Drink, and Screw Mary!
(proudly) I taught him that.
Great.
From my wise, albeit youthful, vantage point, the world is your oyster. You scored big.
You got everything you ever wanted.
Except the girl. The only one that really mattered.
And who might that be?  Miss July? Miss August?
Ted turns to find Julie. His faces brightens with hope.
Julie, wow. I was afraid you left. I was afraid I'd never see you again.
I'm not going anywhere, Ted. You're the one with the champagne wishes and caviar dreams.
I decided to let Helen run the magazine. I need to go to college, learn a few things, you know.
Julie seems pleased.
And I thought maybe I'd take up boating. I've always wanted to be a "coxswain."
Very ambitious. I like that.
The thing is, I'll need a first mate.
I know where you can find any number of naked girls who'd love to hop on board.
All kidding aside, he speaks from the heart...
Julie, you were right. All the naked girls in the world mean nothing. It's the one you want to cover up with your coat that you really love.
Julie smiles...
Planet Ted. Five years from now. What's happening?
I graduated from college. Did great, summa cum laude and all. And I'm about to launch a brand new magazine called "EXPOSED!"  An homage to Miss Julie Conroy of Xenia, Ohio.
Julie grins.
I know where you can find an excellent editor-in-chief.
Yellow pages?
Let your fingers do the walking.
Suddenly the music changes. "People." Ted grins.
They're playing our song.  (extending his hand) Dare I ask for this dance?
(taking his hand) You better.
Ted and Julie begin dancing and kissing in the b.g.    Charlie and Jimmy feign tears.
I'm a sucker for a happy ending. (hugging Jimmy) Hold me.
And we start to RISE AGAIN, above the NELSON HOUSE, into clouds above Xenia...
So, as you can guess, everybody pretty much lived happily ever after. My parents didn't give up the grocery store...
We descend through clouds and quickly find we're...
Mom and Dad take pictures and smooch in front of the pala
...but they did manage to sneak away for a second honeymoon.
We ZOOM CLOSE on "Heaven Magazine," where pages flip open the wind, revealing...

head_text.subj: PRINCIPAL MERKIN "EXPOSED" IN THE PAGES OF "HEAVEN."

text: Merk's appearance in "Heaven" turned out to be a good thing. He was spotted by a talent scout...
Principal Merkin dressed as Barbra, singing "Don't Rain o Parade."
...and went on a European summer tour, fulfilling his lifelong dream. Naturally he brought Poochie, the only girl he ever really loved.
Poochie, the Cocker Spaniel, watches. Wagging her tail.
After graduation, Charlie moved to Utah...
Charlie wrestling in a haystack with the IDENTICAL TAYLOR TRIPLETS.
...where he married all three of the identical Taylor Triplets. Let's just say, they've been very busy...
Peeking out of the haystack, we spot at least a dozen CHA JR's.
And even Uncle Billy landed on his feet.
Uncle Billy wears a phone headset. He seems to be swimmin a sea of "Time-Life" style operators.
...with a two year subscription to "Heaven," you get a free underwater calculator.
And now if you'll excuse me, I think I'll get back to being the coxswain on the ship of life.
Ted and Julie sail off into, what else but a GLORIOUS SUN
